question: Jefferies.
answer: Congratulations, Jeff.

question: For what?
answer: For getting rid of that cast.

question: This is Wednesday.
answer: Gunnison -- how did you get to be such a big editor -- with such a small memory?

question: Wrong day?
answer: Wrong week. Next Wednesday I emerge from this plaster cocoon.

question: That's too bad, Jeff. Well, I guess I can't be lucky every day. Forget I called.
answer: Yeah. I sure feel sorry for you, Gunnison. Must be rough on you thinking of me wearing this cast another whole week.

question: That one week is going to cost me my best photographer -- and you a big assignment.
answer: Where?

question: Where?
answer: Indo-China. Got a code tip from the bureau chief this morning. The place is about to go up in smoke.

question: Didn't I tell you! Didn't I tell you it was the next place to watch?
answer: You did.

question: Okay. When do I leave? Half-hour? An hour?
answer: With that cast on -- you don't.

question: Stop sounding stuffy. I'll take pictures from a jeep. From a water buffalo if necessary.
answer: You're too valuable to the magazine for us to play around with. I'll send Morgan or Lambert.

question: Swell. I get myself half-killed for you -- and you reward me by stealing my assignments.
answer: I didn't ask you to stand in the middle of that automobile race track.

question: You asked for something dramatically different! You got it!
answer: So did you. Goodbye, Jeff.

question: Read some good books.
answer: I've been taking pictures so long I don't know how to read anymore.

question: I'll send you some comic books.
answer: Listen -- if you don't pull me out of this swamp of boredom -- I'll do something drastic.

question: Like what?
answer: I'll -- I'll get married. Then I'll never be able to go anywhere.

question: It's about time you got married -- before you turn into a lonesome and bitter old man.
answer: Can you see me -- rushing home to a hot apartment every night to listen to the automatic laundry, the electric dishwasher, the garbage disposal and a nagging wife.

question: The New York State sentence for a peeping Tom is six months in the workhouse!
answer: Hello Stella.

question: And there aren't any windows in the workhouse. Years ago, they used to put out your eyes with a hot poker. Is one of those bikini bombshells you always watch worth a hot poker? We've grown to be a race of peeping Toms. What people should do is stand outside their own houses and look in once in a while. What do you think of that for homespun philosophy?
answer: Readers' Digest, April, 1939.

question: I can smell trouble right in this apartment. You broke your leg. You look out the window. You see things you shouldn't. Trouble. I can see you now, in front of the judge, flanked by lawyers in blue double- breasted suits. You're pleading, "Judge, it was only innocent fun. I love my neighbors like a father." -- The Judge answers, "Congratulations. You just gave birth to three years in Dannemora."
answer: Right now I'd even welcome trouble.

question: You've got a hormone deficiency.
answer: How can you tell that from a thermometer!

question: Those sultry sun-worshipers you watch haven't raised your temperature one degree in four weeks.
answer: I think you're right. There is going to be some trouble around here.

question: I knew it!
answer: Don't you ever heat that stuff up.

question: Gives your circulation something to fight. What kind of trouble?
answer: Lisa Fremont.

question: You must be kidding. A beautiful young woman, and you a reasonably healthy specimen of manhood.
answer: She expects me to marry her.

question: That's normal.
answer: I don't want to.

question: That's abnormal.
answer: I'm not ready for marriage.

question: Nonsense. A man is always ready for marriage -- with the right girl. And Lisa Fremont is the right girl for any man with half a brain, who can get one eye open.
answer: She's all right.

question: Behind every ridiculous statement is always hidden the true cause. What is it? You have a fight?
answer: No.

question: Her father loading up the shotgun?
answer: Stella!

question: It's happened before, you know! Some of the world's happiest marriage have started 'under the gun' you might say.
answer: She's just not the girl for me.

question: She's only perfect.
answer: Too perfect. Too beautiful, too talented, too sophisticated, too everything -- but what I want.

question: Is what you want something you can discuss?
answer: It's very simple. She belongs in that rarefied atmosphere of Park Avenue, expensive restaurants, and literary cocktail parties.

question: People with sense can belong wherever they're put.
answer: Can you see her tramping around the world with a camera bum who never has more than a week's salary in the bank? If only she was ordinary.

question: You're never going to marry?
answer: Probably. But when I do, it'll be to someone who thinks of life as more than a new dress, a lobster dinner, and the latest scandal. I need a woman who'll go anywhere, do anything, and love it. The only honest thing to do is call it off. Let her look for somebody else.

question: I can just hear you now. "Get out of here you perfect, wonderful woman! You're too good for me!"
answer: That's the hard part.

question: Look, Mr. Jefferies. I'm not educated. I'm not even sophisticated. But I can tell you this -- when a man and a woman see each other, and like each other -- they should come together -- wham like two taxies on Broadway. Not sit around studying each other like specimens in at bottle.
answer: There's an intelligent way to approach marriage.

question: Intelligence! Nothing has caused the human race more trouble. Modern marriage!
answer: We've progressed emotionally in --

question: Baloney! Once it was see somebody, get excited, get married -- Now, it's read books, fence with four syllable words, psychoanalyze each other until you can't tell a petting party from a civil service exam
answer: People have different emotional levels that --

question: Ask for trouble and you get it. Why there's a good boy in my neighborhood who went with a nice girl across the street for three years. Then he refused to marry her. Why? -- Because she only scored sixty-one on a Look Magazine marriage quiz! When I married Myles, we were both maladjusted misfits. We still are. And we've loved every minute of it.
answer: That's fine, Stella. Now would you make me a sandwich?

question: Okay -- but I'm going to spread some common sense on the bread. Lisa Fremont's loaded to her fingertips with love for you. I'll give you two words of advice. Marry her.
answer: She pay you much?

question: The elderly lady is now asleep in her deck chair, her face covered with the Herald Tribune. There is no sign of the man with the flowers.
answer: Jeff's eyes travel up to the ballet dancer's window.

question: She is sitting near the window looking into an upright mirror. Dreamily, and methodically, she is brushing her long copper- colored hair.
answer: His eyes are suddenly turned in another direction, sharply to his left.

question: How's your leg?
answer: Mmmm -- hurts a little.

question: And your stomach?
answer: Empty as a football.

question: And you love life?
answer: Not too active.

question: Anything else bothering you?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Reading from top to bottom -- Lisa -- Carol -- Fremont.
answer: The Lisa Fremont who never wears the same dress twice?

question: Only because it's expected of her. Right off the Paris plane. Think it will sell?
answer: Depends on the quote. Let's see -- there's the plane tickets over, import duties, hidden taxes, profit markups --

question: -- A steal at eleven hundred dollars.
answer: That dress should be listed on the stock exchange.

question: We sell a dozen a day in this price range.
answer: Who buys them? Tax collectors?

question: Even if I had to pay, it would be worth it -- just for the occasion.
answer: Something big going on somewhere?

question: Going on right here. It's a big night.
answer: It's just a run-of-the-mill Monday. The calendar's loaded with them.

question: It's opening night of the last depressing week of L. B. Jefferies in a cast.
answer: Hasn't been any big demand for tickets.

question: That's because I bought out the house. This cigarette box has seen better days.
answer: Picked it up in Shanghai -- which has also seen better days.

question: It's cracked -- and you never use it. And it's too ornate. I'm sending up a plain, flat silver one -- with just your initials engraved.
answer: Now that's no way to spend your hard- earned money!

question: I wanted to, Jeff. Oh! What would you think of starting off with dinner at the "21"?
answer: You have, perhaps, an ambulance outside?

question: Let's open the wine now. It's a Montrachet.
answer: A big glassful.

question: Big enough?
answer: Fine. Corkscrew's on the right.

question: I couldn't think of anything more boring and tiresome than what you've been through. And the last week must be the hardest.
answer: Yeah -- I want to get this thing off and get moving.

question: Thank you.
answer: What a day I've had!

question: Tired?
answer: Not a bit. I was all morning in a sales meeting. Then over to the Waldorf for a quick drink with Madame Dufresne -- just over from Paris. With some spy reports. Back to the "21" for lunch with the Harper's Bazaar people -- that's when I ordered dinner. Then two Fall showings -- twenty blocks apart. Then I had to have a cocktail with Leland and Slim Hayward -- we're trying to get his next show. Then I had to dash back and change.

question: Tell me -- what was Slim Hayward wearing?
answer: She looked very cool. She had on a mint green -- And to think, I planted three nice items about you in the columns today. You can't buy that kind of publicity.

question: That's good news.
answer: Someday you might want to open up your own studio here.

question: How could I run it from say -- Pakistan?
answer: Jeff -- isn't it time you came home? You could pick your assignment.

question: I wish there was one I wanted.
answer: Make the one you want.

question: You mean leave the magazine?
answer: Yes.

question: For what?
answer: For yourself -- and me. I could get you a dozen assignments tomorrow... fashion, portraits -- Don't laugh. -- I could do it!

question: That's what I'm afraid of. Could you see me -- driving down to the fashion salon in a jeep -- wearing combat boots and a three day beard?
answer: I could see you looking handsome and successful in a dark blue flannel suit.

question: Let's not talk any more nonsense, huh?
answer: I'd better start setting up for dinner.

question: Jeff's attention is concentrated on an apartment we have not seen before. This belongs to a single woman, about forty years of age. She lives alone. Her apartment is below that of the salesman with the invalid wife.
answer: Jeff leans forward with increased interest. Behind him we get vague figure of Lisa laying a cloth over the card table.

question: A nearer view show us a more intimate picture of the woman Jeff is concentrating on. She is thin and unattractive. At the moment, she is putting on her make-up in front of the bedroom mirror. She gives a half turn and picks up a pair of horn-rimmed glasses, which she puts on, and leans nearer to her mirror. She picks up a lipstick and proceeds to paint her lips carefully.
answer: Without taking his eyes from the scene, Jeff picks up his wineglass and drinks. As he drinks, his eyes move slightly over. Jeff gives a faint, sympathetic smile, and subconsciously raises his glass in response. In the background, Lisa, having just placed a pair of candlesticks on the table, is returning to the kitchen.

question: There can't be that much difference between people and the way they live! We all eat, talk, drink, laugh, sleep, wear clothes --
answer: Well now, look --

question: If you're saying all this just because you don't want to tell me the truth, because you're hiding something from me, then maybe I can understand --
answer: There's nothing I'm hiding. It's just that --

question: It doesn't make sense to me. What's so different about it here from over there, or any place you go, that one person couldn't live in both places just as easily?
answer: Some people can. Now if you'll let me explain --

question: What is it but traveling from one place to another, taking pictures? It's just like being a tourist on an endless vacation.
answer: All right. That's your opinion. You're entitled to it, but --

question: Oh, I do that all the time. Whenever I have a few minutes after lunch.
answer: Ever get shot at, run over, sandbagged at night because people got unfavorable publicity from your camera? Those high heels would be a lot of use in the jungle -- and those nylons and six-ounce lingerie --

question: Three.
answer: Well, they'd be very stylish in Finland -- just before you froze to death. Begin to get the idea?

question: And it's deflating to find out that the only way I can be part of it -- is to take out a subscription to your magazine. I guess I'm not the girl I thought I was.
answer: There's nothing wrong with you, Lisa. You have the town in the palm of your hand.

question: Not quite -- it seems. Goodbye, Jeff.
answer: You mean "goodnight."

question: I mean what I said.
answer: Lisa! Can't we just sort of keep things status quo?

question: Without any future?
answer: Well -- when'll I see you again?

question: Hello.
answer: Gunnison?

question: Yeah. Is that you, Jeff?
answer: It's me.

question: Something wrong?
answer: The word is "everything." Now what time does my plane leave Tuesday?

question: Jeff --
answer: I don't care where it goes -- just as long as I'm on it.

question: Okay. Indo-China. Tuesday. We'll pick you up.
answer: That's more like it. Goodnight, old buddy.

question: Jeff wakens a little more fully as his attentions is drawn to:
answer: The couple who sleep on the fire escape. The increasing rain cause them to hastily gather their things to retreat inside. The man, hurriedly untying the alarm clock from the railing of the fire escape, lets it slip through his fingers. As if falls to the garden below, the CAMERA FANS SWIFTLY down with it. When the clock hits the ground, the alarm goes off sending a shrill sound through the neighborhood.

question: Jeff smiles at the incident, and then lowers his eyes slightly as something else catches his attention.
answer: Coming out of his apartment into the corridor on the floor below is the salesman with the nagging wife. The shades are drawn in his apartment, but a light burns dimly behind them. The salesman carries a large aluminum suitcase -- the same one we saw him with earlier in the day. The sound of the alarm startles him. He turns toward the window a moment listening. Then reassured that is is nothing important, he turns and moves down the corridor.

question: The insurance Company would be a lot happier if you slept in your bed, not the wheelchair.
answer: How did you know!

question: Eyes bloodshot. Must have been staring out the window for hours.
answer: I was.

question: What'll you do if one of them catches you?
answer: Depends one which one. Now Miss Torso, for example --

question: Keep your mind off her.
answer: She's real eat, drink and be merry girl.

question: And she'll end up fat, alcoholic and miserable.
answer: Speaking of misery, Miss Lonely Hearts drank herself to sleep again. Alone.

question: Poor girl. Someday she'll find her happiness.
answer: And some man will lose his.

question: Isn't there anyone in the neighborhood who might cast an eye in her direction?
answer: Well, the salesman could be available soon.

question: He and his wife splitting up?
answer: It's hard to figure. He went out several time last night, in the rain carrying his sample case.

question: Isn't he a salesman?
answer: Now what could he sell at three in the morning?

question: Flashlights. Luminous dials for watches. House numbers that light up.
answer: He was taking something out of the apartment. I'm certain.

question: His personal effects. He's probably running away -- the coward.
answer: Sometimes it's worse to stay than it is to run.

question: But it takes a particularly low type of man to do it. What about this morning? Any developments?
answer: No. The shades are still drawn in their apartment.

question: Get back! Out of sight! Quick!
answer: What is it? What's the matter?

question: The salesman's looking out his window.
answer: A Federal offense.

question: Get back there! He'll see you!
answer: I'm not shy. I've been looked at before.

question: And don't sleep in the chair again.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Great conversationalist.
answer: Stella. Will you take those binoculars out of the case and bring them to me.

question: Well, "ain't I?" -- Pay attention to me.
answer: I'm not exactly on the other side of the room.

question: Your mind is. And when I want a man, I want all of him.
answer: Don't you ever have any problems?

question: I have one now.
answer: So do I.

question: Tell me about it.
answer: Why would a man leave his apartment three times, on a rainy night, with a suitcase? And come back three times?

question: He likes the way his wife welcomes him home.
answer: Not that salesman's wife. And why didn't he go to work today?

question: Homework. It's more interesting.
answer: What's interesting about a butcher's knife and a small saw wrapped up in a newspaper?

question: Nothing, thank heaven.
answer: Why hasn't he gone into his wife's bedroom all day?

question: I wouldn't dare answer that.
answer: Lisa -- there's something terribly wrong.

question: And I'm afraid it's with me.
answer: What do you think?

question: Jeff -- if you could only see yourself.
answer: Now, Lisa --

question: Sitting around, looking out a window to kill time, is one thing -- but doing it the way you are -- -- with, with binoculars, and with wild opinions about every little movement you see -- is, is diseased!
answer: Do you think I consider this recreation?

question: I don't know what you consider it -- but if you don't stop it, I'm getting out of here.
answer: You'd better before you catch the disease!

question: What is it you're looking for?
answer: I want to find out what's wrong with the salesman's wife. Does that make me sound like a madman?

question: What makes you think something's wrong with her? A lot of things. She's an invalid who needs constant care -- and yet the husband nor anyone else has been in there all day. Maybe she died.
answer: Where's the doctor -- the undertakers?

question: She could be under sedatives, sleeping. He's in the room now.
answer: Lisa, please!

question: There's nothing to see.
answer: There is -- I've seen things through that window! Bickering, family fights, mysterious trips at night, knives, saws, rope -- and since last evening, not a sight or sound of his wife! Now you tell me where she is and what she's doing!

question: Maybe he's leaving his wife. I don't know, and I don't care. Lots of people have saws, knives and ropes around their houses. Lots of men don't speak to their wives all day. Lots of wives nag, and men hate them, and trouble starts -- but very, very, very few of them end up in murder -- if that's what you're thinking.
answer: It's pretty hard to stay away from that word isn't is?

question: You could see all the things he did, couldn't you?
answer: What are you getting at?

question: You could see that he did because he had the shades in his apartment up, and walked along the corridor, and the streets and the backyard?
answer: Yeah.

question: Jeff, do you think a murderer would let you see all that? That he shouldn't keep his shades down and hide behind them?
answer: That's where he's being clever. Acting nonchalant.

question: Stella, I -- I can't tell you what a welcome sight this is. No wonder your husband's still in love with you.
answer: Police?

question: Huh?
answer: You called the police?

question: Oh. Well, yes and no. It wasn't an official call. He's just a friend. An old, ornery friend.
answer: Now just where do you suppose he cut her up? Oh -- of course! In the bathtub. That's the only place he could wash away the blood.

question: Jeff's eyes, over the coffee cup, are staring intently at the backyard.
answer: Thorwald's apartment. The shades up. No one moving.

question: His eyes stray in an upward direction as he puts down the coffee cup.
answer: The CAMERA PANS UP past the woman lowering the dog, up to the roof where one of the sunbathers can be seen sitting up, rubbing her body with sun tan oil.

question: Jeff's eyes moves down again. Abstractedly his hand strays toward the piece of bacon. He picks it up.
answer: Thorwald's apartment. We are now aware that the salesman is now in his living room, lying out of sight on the sofa, because the smoke from a newly lighted cigar is starting to ascend toward the ceiling of his room.

question: You didn't see the killing, or the body? How do you know there was a murder?
answer: Because everything that man's done has been suspicious. Trips at night in the rain, saws, knives, trunks with rope, and a wife that isn't there any more.

question: I'll admit it all has a mysterious sound -- but is could mean a number of different things. Murder is the least likely.
answer: Go ahead, Doyle -- tell me he's an unemployed magician -- amusing the neighborhood with sleight-of-hand.

question: It's too stupid and obvious a way to murder -- in full view of fifty windows -- and then sit over there -- -- smoking a cigar -- waiting for the police to pick him up.
answer: Well, officer -- do your duty.

question: You've got a lot to lean about homicide, Jeff. Morons have committed murder so shrewdly that it took a hundred trained police minds to catch them. That salesman wouldn't just knock off his wife after dinner, toss her in a trunk and put her in storage.
answer: I'll bet it's been done.

question: Almost everything's been done -- under panic. But this is a thousand to one shot. That man's still sitting around his apartment; he isn't panicked.
answer: You think I made all this up?

question: I think you saw something -- that probably has a very simple explanation.
answer: For instance?

question: His wife took a trip.
answer: She -- was -- an -- invalid!

question: You told me. I've got to run, Jeff.
answer: All right -- you don't believe me.

question: I -- uh -- won't report it to the Department. Let me poke into a little on my own. No point in you getting any ridiculous publicity.
answer: Thanks.

question: We know the wife is gone. I'll see if I can find out where.
answer: Do that.

question: He has a six months lease, and has used up a little over five and a half months of it. Quiet. Drinks, but not to drunkenness. Pays his bill promptly, with money earned as a consume jewelry salesman -- wholesale. Keeps to himself, and none of the neighbors got close to him, or his wife.
answer: I think they missed their chance with her.

question: She never left the apartment --
answer: Then where is she -- in the ice box?

question: -- until yesterday morning.
answer: What time?

question: Six ayem.
answer: I think that's about the time I fell asleep.

question: Too bad. The Thorwalds were just leaving the apartment house at that time. Feel a little foolish?
answer: Not yet.

question: How's your wife?
answer: Oh -- oh, she's fine. Just fine.

question: Who said they left then?
answer: Who left -- where?

question: The Thorwalds -- at six in the morning?
answer: The building superintendent, and two tenants. Flat statements -- no hesitation. And they all jibed to the letter. The Thorwalds were leaving for the railroad station.

question: Now how could anybody guess that? They had, perhaps, signs on their luggage, "Grand Central Or Bust!"?
answer: The superintendent met Thorwald coming back. He said Thorwald told him he had just put his wife on the train for the country.

question: A very convenient guy -- this superintendent. Have you checked his bank deposits lately?
answer: Jeff -- huh?

question: Well -- what good is his information?!! It's a second-hand version of an unsupported statement by the murderer himself -- Thorwald! Anybody actually see the wife get on the train?
answer: I hate to remind you -- but this all started because you said she was murdered. Now did anyone, including you, actually see her murdered?

question: Doyle -- are you interested in solving a case, or making me look foolish?
answer: If possible -- both.

question: Well then do a good job of it! Get over there, and search Thorwald's apartment! It must be knee-deep in evidence.
answer: I can't do that.

question: I mean when he goes out for a paper, or a drink, or something. What he doesn't know won't hurt him.
answer: I can't do it even if he's gone.

question: What's the matter? Does he have a courtesy card from the police department?
answer: Now don't get me mad! Even a detective can't walk in anybody's apartment and search it. If I were ever caught in there, I'd lose my badge inside of ten minutes!

question: Just make sure you're not caught. If you find something, you've got a murderer and nobody will care about a couple of house rules. If you find nothing -- he's clear.
answer: At the risk of sounding stuffy, Jeff -- I'll remind you of the Constitution, and the phrase "search warrant" issued by a judge who knows the Bill of Rights verbatim. He must ask for evidence.

question: Give him evidence.
answer: I can hear myself starting out. "Your Honor -- I have a friend who's an amateur sleuth, an one night, after a heavy supper --" He'd throw the New York State Penal Code right in my face. -- And it's six volumes.

question: By morning there might not be anything left to find in his apartment.
answer: A detective's nightmare.

question: What do you need before you can search -- bloody footsteps leading up to the door?
answer: One thing I don't need is heckling! You called and asked me for help -- and now you're acting like a taxpayer! How did we ever stand each other in that same plane for three years?

question: You know, every day for three years I asked myself that same question?
answer: Ever get an answer?

question: Yeah -- frequently -- it ran something like this
answer: Sorry I had to turn it down. I'm going over to the railroad station and check Thorwald's story.

question: Forget the story -- find the trunk. Mrs. Thorwald's in it!
answer: Oh -- I almost forgot! There was a postcard in Thorwald's mailbox. Mailed yesterday afternoon, three- thirty P.M. from Merritsville -- -- That's eighty miles north of here. The message read "Arrived O.K. Already feeling better. Love, Anna."

question: Is -- is Anna -- who I think it is?
answer: Mrs. Thorwald. Anything you need?

question: Hello.
answer: Mrs. Doyle?

question: Yes.
answer: Jeff again. Has Tom come in yet?

question: Not yet, Jeff.
answer: You haven't even heard from him?

question: Not a word. It is something really important, Jeff?
answer: I'm afraid it is, Tess.

question: I'll have him call the moment I hear from him.
answer: Tell him not to waste time calling. To get over here soon as he can. I think Thorwald's pulling out tonight.

question: Who's Thorwald?
answer: He knows. Don't worry, Tess. It's a man.

question: Goodnight, you idiot.
answer: Goodnight, Mrs Doyle.

question: That alligator bag his wife had on the bedpost --
answer: What about it?

question: He had it hidden in the dresser! Well, at least it was in there. He took it out, went to the phone and called somebody long distance. -- His wife's jewelry was in the handbag. And something about it worried him. He was asking somebody advice over the phone.
answer: Someone not his wife?

question: He must have gone somewhere to the right.
answer: All day long I've tried to keep my mind on work.

question: Thinking about Thorwald?
answer: And you, and you friend Doyle -- Did you hear from him again -- since he left?

question: Not a word. He was going to check on the railroad station, and the trunk. He must be still on it. Something on your mind, Lisa?
answer: It doesn't make sense to me.

question: What doesn't?
answer: Women aren't that unpredictable.

question: Lisa -- I can't guess what you're thinking.
answer: A woman has a favorite handbag -- it always hangs on her bedpost where she can get at it. Then she takes a trip and leaves it behind. Why?

question: Because she didn't know she was going on a trip -- and where she was going she wouldn't need a handbag.
answer: But only her husband would know that. And the jewelry! Women don't keep all their jewelry in a purse, all tangled, getting scratched and twisted up.

question: Do they hide it in their husband's clothes?
answer: They do not! And they don't leave it behind them. A woman going anywhere but the hospital would always take makeup, perfume and jewelry.

question: Inside stuff?
answer: Basic equipment. You don't leave it behind in your husband's drawer in your favorite handbag.

question: I'm with you, sweetie, but Detective Thomas J. Doyle has a pat answer for that.
answer: That Mrs. Thorwald left at six ayem yesterday with her husband?

question: That's what the witnesses told him.
answer: Well, I have a pat rebuttal for Mr. Doyle -- that couldn't be Mrs. Thorwald -- or I don't know women.

question: Still -- those witnesses.
answer: We'll agree they saw a woman -- but she wasn't Mrs. Thorwald. -- That is, yet.

question: Come here.
answer: I'd like to see your friend's face when we tell him. He doesn't sound like much of a detective.

question: Don't be too hard on him. He's a steady worker. I wish he'd get there, though.
answer: Don't rush me. We have all night.

question: We have all -- what?
answer: Night. I'm going to stay with you.

question: You'll have to clear that through my landlord --
answer: I have the whole weekend off.

question: Well that's fine, but I only have one bed, and --
answer: Say anything else, and I'll stay tomorrow night too.

question: Lisa, I won't be able to give you any -- -- pajamas.
answer: You said I'd have to live out of one suitcase I'll bet yours isn't this small?

question: That's a suitcase?
answer: A Mark Cross overnight case, anyway. Compact, but ample enough. I'll trade you -- my feminine intuition for a bed for the night.

question: I'd be no better than Thorwald, to refuse.
answer: There's that song again.

question: Where does a man get the inspiration for a song like that?
answer: From his landlord -- once a month.

question: It's utterly beautiful. I wish I could be creative.
answer: You are. You have a talent for creating difficult situations.

question: I do?
answer: Staying the night here, uninvited.

question: Surprise -- is the most important element of attack. And beside, you're not up on your private eye literature. When they're in trouble, it's always their Girl Friday who gets them out of it.
answer: The same girl who keeps him out of the clutches of seductive show girls, and over-passionate daughters of the rich.

question: The same.
answer: But he never ends up marrying her. Strange.

question: Weird. Why don't I slip into something comfortable?
answer: You mean -- like the kitchen? And make us some coffee?

question: Doyle is relaxed.
answer: There isn't any "case" to be through with, Miss Fremont. Now let's get down to that friendly drink.

question: Jeff and Lisa remain unmoved. A little self-conscious, Doyle checks his watch, and says with a pleasant laugh:
answer: Maybe you're right. I guess I'd better get home and get some sleep.

question: Jeff and Lisa deadpan. Doyle is wiping his coat lapels with a handkerchief. He looks at them pleasantly.
answer: I'm not much of a snifter. If you need any more help, Jeff -- consult the yellow pages of your telephone directory.

question: As much as I hate to give Thomas J. Doyle too much credit, he might have gotten a hold of something when he said this was pretty private stuff going on out there. Do you suppose it's ethical to watch a man with binoculars, and a long- focus lens -- until you can see the freckles on the back of his neck, and almost read his mail -- do you suppose it's ethical even if you prove he didn't commit a crime?
answer: I'm not much on rear window ethics.

question: Of course, they have the same chance. They can look at me like a bug under glass, if they want to.
answer: Jeff -- if anybody walked in here, I don't think they'd believe what they see.

question: Huh?
answer: You and me with long faces -- plunged into despair -- because we find out that a man didn't kill his wife. We're two of the most frightening ghouls I've ever known. You'd think we could be a little bit happy that the poor woman is alive and well. Whatever happened to that old saying "Love Thy Neighbor."

question: I think I'll start reviving it tomorrow, with say -- Miss Torso for a start?
answer: Not if I have to move into an apartment across the courtyard and do the dance of the seven veils once an hour. Show's over for tonight. Preview -- of the coming attractions. Did Mr. Doyle think I stole this case.

question: What do you think? I'll rephrase the question.
answer: Thank you.

question: Do you like it?
answer: Well, -- if there was one less thread this way -- -- and two less that way -- -- I might give up bachelorhood.

question: I wonder.
answer: What?

question: Miss Lonely Hearts just laid out something that looks like sodium trieckonal capsules.
answer: You can tell that from here?

question: I handled enough of those red pills to put everybody in New Jersey asleep for the winter.
answer: Would four of them -- ?

question: No -- but it makes the rest easy to take. And she's reading the Bible.
answer: Then I wouldn't worry too much. But let's keep an eye on her.

question: What are you two talking about?
answer: Got a shovel?

question: No.
answer: There's probably one in the basement.

question: Go ahead, Thorwald -- pick it up. You're curious. You wonder if it's your girl friend calling. The one you killed for. Pick it up, Thorwald!
answer: Hello.

question: Did you get my note? Well -- did you get it, Thorwald?
answer: Who are you?

question: I'll give you a chance to find out. Meet me in the bar at the Brevoort -- and do it right away.
answer: Why should I?

question: For a little business meeting -- to settle the estate of your late wife.
answer: I don't know what you mean.

question: Now stop wasting time, Thorwald, or I'll hang up and call the police.
answer: I only have a hundred dollars or so.

question: This is the baby sitter.
answer: Oh. When are they expected home?

question: I'm hired 'til one. They went to dinner and maybe night-clubbing.
answer: Well, if he calls in, tell him to get in touch with L. B. Jefferies right away. I might have quite a surprise for him.

question: Does he have your number, Mr. Jefferies?
answer: He has it. Thank you.

question: A man is assaulting a woman at one two five west ninth street. Second floor rear. Make it fast.
answer: Your name?

question: L. B. Jefferies.
answer: Phone number?

question: Chelsea 2-5598.
answer: Two minutes.

question: When you took your first snapshot -- did you ever think it would bring you to this?
answer: Stella -- how long do you think he'll stay there?

question: Unless he's dumber than I think, he won't wait 'til his lease is up.
answer: My billfold! In the right hand drawer.

question: What do you need money for?
answer: To bail Lisa out of jail.

question: You know -- you could just leave her there until after next Tuesday -- so you could sneak away safely -- as planned.
answer: One hundred and twenty-seven.

question: How much do you think you'll need?
answer: First offense burglary -- -- probably two-fifty. The piggy bank.

question: Ten here.
answer: Thirty-three here. Totals one-ninety. Not enough.

question: I got twenty or so in my purse. Give me what you've got.
answer: What about the rest?

question: When those cops get a look at Miss Fremont -- they'll even contribute.
answer: Just a minute. I'll tell you who it is when you get back. Jefferies.

question: Just a minute. I'll tell you who it is when you get back. Jefferies.
answer: This is Doyle, Jeff.

question: Tom, I've got something real big for you.
answer: Look Jeff, don't louse up my night with another man killer stuffing a grisly trunk that turns out to be --

question: Listen to me! Lisa's been arrested.
answer: Your Lisa?

question: My Lisa. She went into Thorwald's apartment, and he came back. The only way I could get her out was to call the police.
answer: I told you that --

question: I know what you told me! She went in to get evidence, and she came out with it.
answer: Like what?

question: Like Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring. If that woman were still alive, she'd be wearing it.
answer: A possibility.

question: A fact! Last night he killed a dog for pawing in his garden. Why? Because he had something buried in there. Something a dog could scent.
answer: Like an old hambone?

question: I don't know what pet name Thorwald had for his wife. And that night he went out half a dozen times with the metal suitcase. He wasn't taking his possessions, because they're up in his apartment now!
answer: You think perhaps it was "old hambone?"

question: In sections! And one other thing, doubting Tom -- it just occurred to me that all the calls Thorwald made were long distance! If he called his wife the day she left -- after she arrived in Merritsville -- why did she need to send him a postcard saying she'd arrived?
answer: Where'd they take Lisa?

question: Precinct Six. I sent a friend over with bail money.
answer: Maybe you won't need it. I'll run it down, Jeff.

question: Can you get me that ring back?
answer: No.

question: Tell her to bring it back!
answer: I can't. The police have it by now.
